column2: Refers to an adverse response or side effect that occurs after the administration of a medication, ranging from mild symptoms like nausea or drowsiness to severe conditions such as allergic reactions or organ damage.

A mosquito-borne infectious disease caused by parasites of the Plasmodium genus. It typically presents with symptoms such as fever, chills, headache, and muscle aches. If left untreated, it can lead to severe complications and even death. Treatment involves antimalarial medications and preventive measures such as mosquito control and the use of bed nets.

Is an exaggerated immune response to a substance that is usually harmless to most people. When an allergic individual comes into contact with an allergen, such as pollen, dust mites, pet dander, or certain foods, their immune system overreacts, leading to various symptoms. These symptoms can range from mild, such as sneezing, itching, or a rash, to severe, including difficulty breathing, swelling, or anaphylaxis. Allergies can be managed through avoidance of triggers, medication, and allergy shots (immunotherapy).

Is a condition characterized by an underactive thyroid gland, which fails to produce enough thyroid hormones. These hormones play a crucial role in regulating metabolism, energy levels, and various bodily functions. Symptoms of hypothyroidism can include fatigue, weight gain, dry skin, sensitivity to cold, depression, and sluggishness. The condition is commonly treated with thyroid hormone replacement therapy to restore hormone levels and alleviate symptoms. Regular monitoring and medication adjustments may be necessary to maintain optimal thyroid function.

A chronic autoimmune skin disorder characterized by the rapid buildup of skin cells, resulting in the formation of thick, red patches with silvery scales. It is caused by an overactive immune system that mistakenly targets healthy skin cells, leading to their accelerated production. Psoriasis commonly affects areas like the scalp, elbows, knees, and lower back, but can occur anywhere on the body. The condition is associated with itching, discomfort, and sometimes joint pain. Treatment options include topical creams, oral medications, phototherapy, and biologic injections, aiming to control symptoms, reduce inflammation, and slow down skin cell growth.
A chronic digestive condition characterized by the backflow of stomach acid into the esophagus, leading to symptoms such as heartburn and regurgitation.
Is a long-term liver condition characterized by impaired bile flow, resulting in the accumulation of bile acids in the liver and bloodstream.

Is a highly contagious viral infection that affects the liver, typically transmitted through contaminated food or water. It causes inflammation of the liver and can lead to symptoms such as fatigue, jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes), nausea, abdominal pain, and loss of appetite. Most individuals recover fully without treatment, but rest and supportive care are recommended. Vaccination and practicing good hygiene, including proper handwashing, can help prevent the spread of hepatitis A.

Is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of cartilage, the cushioning tissue between bones. It commonly affects weight-bearing joints such as the knees, hips, and spine, causing pain, stiffness, and reduced mobility. Osteoarthritis typically develops gradually and is associated with aging, joint overuse, and genetic factors.

A type of vertigo characterized by brief episodes of dizziness or spinning sensations triggered by specific head movements. It is caused by the displacement of small calcium crystals in the inner ear, disrupting the normal balance signals. Common symptoms include sudden onset of vertigo when changing positions, such as rolling over in bed or looking up. Diagnosis is typically made through a physical examination and specific head movement tests.

Refers to a condition characterized by abnormally low blood sugar levels. It typically occurs in individuals with diabetes who take medications such as insulin or certain oral diabetes drugs. Symptoms of hypoglycemia can vary but often include shakiness, sweating, dizziness, confusion, irritability, and weakness. If left untreated, it can lead to more severe symptoms such as seizures or loss of consciousness.

A common skin condition characterized by the presence of pimples, blackheads, whiteheads, and inflammation. It occurs when hair follicles become clogged with oil, dead skin cells, and bacteria. Acne most commonly appears on the face, but can also affect the chest, back, and other areas of the body. Factors such as hormonal changes, excessive oil production, certain medications, and genetics can contribute to acne development.

A chronic medical condition characterized by high levels of blood glucose (blood sugar). It occurs when the body either does not produce enough insulin (a hormone that regulates blood sugar) or cannot effectively use the insulin it produces. There are three main types of diabetes: type 1, type 2, and gestational diabetes.

Is a highly contagious bacterial skin infection characterized by the presence of red sores or blisters that can break open and form a yellowish-brown crust. It is primarily caused by the bacteria Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes. Impetigo commonly affects children, especially in areas with broken skin due to cuts, insect bites, or existing skin conditions.

Also known as high blood pressure, is a chronic medical condition characterized by elevated pressure in the arteries. It occurs when the force exerted by the blood against the walls of the blood vessels is consistently too high. Hypertension is often referred to as the "silent killer" because it typically does not cause noticeable symptoms in its early stages.

Is a condition characterized by open sores or ulcers that develop in the lining of the stomach, upper small intestine (duodenum), or esophagus. These ulcers occur when the protective lining of the digestive tract is eroded, allowing stomach acid and digestive juices to irritate the underlying tissue.

Also known as mixed hemorrhoids or mixed piles, refer to a type of hemorrhoids that exhibit characteristics of both internal and external hemorrhoids. Hemorrhoids are swollen blood vessels in the anal or rectal area.

Is highly contagious and spreads through respiratory droplets when an infected person coughs, sneezes, or talks. It can also spread by touching contaminated surfaces and then touching the nose or mouth.

Also known as varicella, is a highly contagious viral infection caused by the varicella-zoster virus (VZV). It is characterized by a widespread rash of itchy, fluid-filled blisters that form on the skin. Chickenpox is primarily a childhood disease but can affect people of all ages. The virus spreads through respiratory droplets from an infected person or by direct contact with the fluid from the blisters.

Is a degenerative condition that affects the joints and discs of the cervical spine (neck). It occurs due to the wear and tear of the cartilage and bones in the neck over time, often associated with aging.

Is a condition where the thyroid gland becomes overactive, resulting in excessive production of thyroid hormones and causing symptoms such as increased metabolism, weight loss, rapid heartbeat, and nervousness.

(UTI) is an infection that can occur in any part of the urinary system, including the kidneys, bladder, ureters, and urethra. It is most commonly caused by bacteria entering the urinary tract through the urethra.

Are enlarged and twisted veins that commonly occur in the legs. They develop when the valves within the veins that help blood flow back to the heart become weak or damaged, causing blood to pool and veins to enlarge. Risk factors for varicose veins include age, family history, prolonged standing or sitting, obesity, and pregnancy.

is a late stage of HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) infection. It is a chronic and potentially life-threatening condition that affects the immune system, leaving the body vulnerable to various infections and diseases.

is the loss of muscle function in part or all of the body, resulting in the inability to move or control certain muscles. It can occur due to various causes, including spinal cord injuries, nerve damage, stroke, brain injuries, or certain medical conditions.

Is a bacterial infection caused by the bacterium Salmonella enterica serotype Typhi. It is primarily transmitted through contaminated food or water, typically in areas with poor sanitation and hygiene practices.

Is a viral infection that primarily affects the liver. It is caused by the hepatitis B virus (HBV) and can lead to both acute and chronic liver disease. HBV is transmitted through contact with the blood or other body fluids of an infected person.

Also known as a mycosis, is an infection caused by a fungus. Fungi are microorganisms that can live on the skin, nails, and mucous membranes of the body. While some fungi are harmless, others can cause infections, especially when there is an overgrowth or imbalance in the body's natural microbial environment.

Is a viral infection that primarily affects the liver. It is caused by the hepatitis C virus (HCV) and can lead to both acute and chronic liver disease. HCV is primarily transmitted through contact with infected blood, such as through sharing needles or equipment for injecting drugs, unsafe medical procedures or transfusions, or less commonly, through sexual contact or from mother to child during childbirth.

Is a neurological condition characterized by recurring episodes of moderate to severe headaches. These headaches are typically pulsating or throbbing and often affect one side of the head. Migraines are often accompanied by other symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, sensitivity to light, sound, or smells, and can be disabling for the affected individual.

Commonly referred to as asthma, is a chronic respiratory condition characterized by inflammation and narrowing of the airways. It causes recurrent episodes of wheezing, coughing, shortness of breath, and chest tightness. These symptoms occur due to the increased sensitivity and hyperreactivity of the airways to certain triggers.

Is a condition characterized by inflammation and liver damage caused by excessive alcohol consumption over an extended period of time. It is a form of alcoholic liver disease and is typically seen in individuals who engage in heavy or chronic alcohol abuse.

Is a medical condition characterized by yellowing of the skin, eyes, and mucous membranes. It occurs when there is an excess of bilirubin, a yellow pigment produced during the normal breakdown of red blood cells, in the body.

Is a viral infection that primarily affects the liver. It is caused by the hepatitis E virus (HEV) and is typically transmitted through the consumption of contaminated food or water. Hepatitis E is most commonly found in areas with inadequate sanitation and hygiene practices.

Is a viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes, primarily the Aedes mosquito species. It is prevalent in tropical and subtropical regions around the world. Dengue fever is characterized by a sudden onset of high fever, severe headache, joint and muscle pain, rash, and mild bleeding tendencies, such as nosebleeds or easy bruising.

Also known as delta hepatitis, is a viral infection caused by the hepatitis D virus (HDV). HDV is an incomplete virus that requires the presence of the hepatitis B virus (HBV) to replicate and cause infection. Hepatitis D can occur either as a co-infection with HBV or as a superinfection in individuals who are already chronically infected with HBV.

Occurs when there is a sudden blockage of blood flow to the heart muscle. This blockage is usually caused by a clot that forms in one of the coronary arteries, which supply oxygen-rich blood to the heart.

Is an infection that causes inflammation and swelling in the air sacs of the lungs. It can be caused by a variety of infectious agents, including bacteria, viruses, fungi, or parasites. Pneumonia can affect people of all ages but is more common in young children, older adults, and individuals with weakened immune systems.
Refers to a group of conditions characterized by inflammation and damage to the joints. There are several types of arthritis, with the most common being osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis.

Commonly known as the stomach flu, is an inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract that causes symptoms such as diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and nausea. It is usually caused by viral or bacterial infections, although it can also result from parasites or certain medications.

Is a contagious bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It primarily affects the lungs but can also involve other parts of the body, such as the kidneys, spine, or brain. TB is spread through the air when an infected individual coughs, sneezes, or speaks, allowing the bacteria to be inhaled by others.
